quote: Captain's Log, Stardate 46235.7   Ensign Ro, Keiko O'Brien, Guinan   and I are returning to the   Enterprise after a fascinating   visit to the planet Marlonia.
... and I found these pieces in   the tertiary level of the dig.   They're typical of second century   Marlonian cookware.
Mmmm-hmmmm.
Now, see these markings...   they're very similar to some early   Taguan designs... but the   patterns are more intricate...   closer to Buranian than Taguan.
So... you went to one of the most   beautiful planets in this quadrant   and spent your entire shore   leave... in a cave.
It was a very rewarding   experience.       Look at these fragments... they're   in nearly perfect condition...   and they're over seven hundred   years old.
So's my father.
Is that a Draebidium Froctus?
Draebidium Calimus actually...   you can tell by the shape of the   leaves.
I didn't know you were interested   in plant biology.
I... took a class at the   Academy... I just remember a few   things...
Enterprise to Shuttlecraft   Fermi...
This is the Fermi. Go ahead   Enterprise.
We have just received a distress   signal from the Starfleet science   team on Ligos Seven.
Any indication of the problem?
No, sir. The call was cut off   mid-transmission.
Lay in a course and prepare to   engage at Warp eight once we're   aboard.
Aye, sir.
We'll rendezvous with the ship   in three minutes, sir.
We're caught in some kind of   energy field.
Hard about, full impulse.
Aye, sir.
What's happening, Mister Worf?
The shuttle's been enveloped by   an energy field, sir.
Their engines and life support   have failed.
Increase to full impulse.       Bridge to Transporter Room Three.   Prepare to beam the shuttle crew   aboard once we're in range.
Ready, sir.
There's too much interference...   I can't contact the Enterprise...
Transfer auxiliary power to the   inertial dampers...
Warning. Structural failure   imminent.
O'Brien, do you have them?
I'm trying, sir... I can't get   a pattern lock.
The shuttle's coming apart, Chief.   You've got to do it now.
I've got them.       There's a forty percent drop in   mass. I may have lost one of   them...
Thank you, Mister O'Brien.   Another moment and...
According to the bio-scans, their   DNA structures are now consistent   with those of pre-adolescents.   But as far as I can tell, only   their bodies have changed.
Their individual intelligence and   behavioral responses are all   exactly the same as they were   before the accident.
What happened to the shuttlecraft,   Number One?
The shuttle broke up just after   we beamed you out. Data's   coordinating the salvage effort   right now.       Sir.
What about the energy field the   shuttle passed through?
We've been trying to scan it, but   it's putting out a lot of   interference. It's going to take   some time.

We can't afford to stay here any   longer. We'll leave a class four   probe behind to study the energy   field but the distress signal   from Ligos Seven has top priority.       Let me know as soon as you have   any further information, Doctor.   Number One, you're with me.
Captain... there are some   additional tests I'd like to   run...
Of course...       The three of you will remain as   needed to assist Doctor Crusher.
What?
You know... you make a pretty   cute kid.
Great. Just what I want to be...   cute.
Were you this much fun when you   were a kid?
I was in a refugee camp. "Fun"   wasn't exactly in my vocabulary.
What about now? You're not in   that camp anymore.
"Fun" is being back at work...   in my own uniform.
Bridge.
Mister Worf. Prepare to launch   a class four probe to study the   energy field.

I realize how unusual this must   seem...       My appearance is the result of   an accident, involving myself and   three other crew members... the   effects of which Doctor Crusher   is currently working to remedy.       I assure you, I am Captain Picard.
The probe. Aye, sir.
Mister Data, have you secured all   of the shuttle debris?
Almost, sir. It is being stored   in Shuttlebay Two.
Very well.       Ensign, as soon as Mister Data   is finished take us to Ligos at   warp eight.
Captain, may I see you privately   for a few moments?
Of course.
Tea. Earl Grey. Hot.       Have you been able to determine   the cause of our transformation?
Not yet. I'm still waiting for   some test results.
I see.
There are one hundred and three   members of the science team on   Ligos Seven. We should prepare   shuttlebay three for a triage   center in case they have large   numbers of casualties.
We'll be ready.
Ligos Seven is prone to periodic   volcanic activity... perhaps the   planet has entered an active   phase---
Jean-Luc.       I think we need to talk.
All right. Let's talk.       Are you here to relieve me of   duty?
I'd rather not have to take that   step.
I am still Jean-Luc Picard. My   judgement, my experiences, my   mental capacities are all   intact.
That's true... for now. This   could be the first stage of a   condition which may begin to   affect your mind as well.
But you've seen no evidence of   that?
Not yet.       What I do know is that the Captain   of this ship has just gone through   an extreme physical   transformation... the ultimate   effects of which I can't even   begin to guess.
You are asking me to step down.
You're still Jean-Luc Picard...   what do you think you should do?
Commander Riker, please take   command of the ship until further   notice.
Understood, sir.
So what the hell am I supposed   to do now?
You're not supposed to do   anything. That's what "relieved   of duty" means.
Well, I should be doing   something... instead of just   standing around waiting for them   to find a cure.
You're right.       Let's go play.
What?
I haven't been young for a long   time... and I intend to enjoy   every minute of it.
Fine. Enjoy yourself.
What are you going to do... go   back to your room and pout?
I am not twelve years old. If   I want to go to my quarters and   contemplate my situation, it does   not mean that I am... pouting.
Okay, okay.
I could use a... cup of coffee.   How about you?
I'll get it.       Two coffees... one with cream...
Black... double sweet...
I know.       One double sweet.
Careful... that's hot...
Miles...
Sorry.
What's wrong?
It's... I don't know... but this   feels wrong, somehow.
Miles Edward O'Brien. I am still   your wife.
Technically, yes.
Technically?
No. I mean, of course you're my   wife... but you're also ten years   old.
Beverly said it's actually closer   to twelve.
That's not the point.
So what is the point? Is our   marriage over?
I didn't say that. But until they   find a way to reverse this... this   effect... it's going to be hard   for me to ignore the fact that   you're a little girl.
What if they can't find a way?   What if I'm like this the rest   of my life? What does that mean   for us, for our family?
Mommy?
What's wrong, Sweetheart?
I want Mommy to read me a story.
All right. What story would you   like to hear?
I want Mommy.
What if Daddy reads you a story   tonight? Will that be okay?
I'll be right back.
Keiko...
It's going to be all right... I   promise... we'll work this out...
How?
I don't know.

First Officer's Log: Supplemental.   The Enterprise has reached the   Ligos system, and we have begun   to search for the missing   Federation science team. Doctor   Crusher reports no progress on   finding a cure for the members   of the shuttle crew.
Come.
I came to see how you're doing.
I'll have to speak to my tailor,   but otherwise I'm well, thank you.
It's just so... ridiculous. I   can't really take myself seriously   like this...
What's wrong?
Counselor... if Doctor Crusher   can't find a cure... and I have   to stay this way... no one's going   to take me seriously, are they?

I would say the people who know   you, who've worked with you for   years, will be able to make the   adjustment eventually.       But... there are some cultures   that would not accept a   twelve-year-old captain as a   negotiating partner or a credible   emissary.
In that case, I suppose I'll have   to wait until... I grow up again   before I'll get another command.       That could be ten years... maybe   fifteen...
The question is... what to do   until then?
You're still a captain... I'm sure   there are other assignments you   could be given.
I've spent thirty years of my life   aboard starships... I'm not about   to sit behind a desk now.
You could return to the Academy...   get another degree... brush up   on your Latin.

And be Wesley's room-mate, I   suppose.       I will admit that returning to   the Academy does have a certain   appeal... but I've always spent   my life looking forward... going   to the Academy again feels like...   looking back.
Then perhaps you could use this   time to explore another interest...   archeology for instance?
Leave Starfleet?
Not permanently... just a   sabbatical. You could spend ten   years crawling through caves and   digging up artifacts... and still   have enough time to become the   youngest admiral in Starfleet.
It would give me a chance to   accompany Doctor Langford on her   exploration of the ruins on Suvin   Four... but to leave the   Enterprise...
In a way, you're very lucky. You   have a chance do what most people   can only dream about... have a   second childhood without the pain   of growing up.

This is Captain Picard's   rybo-viroxic-nucleic structure   from a tissue sample I took this   morning. It's the same as a sample   I took before the accident --   except it's missing several key   viroxic sequences.
I'm afraid it's been a long time   since I took genetics, Doctor.

RVN is one of the key factors in   our development during puberty.   Unlike DNA, which never changes,   RVN takes on additional viroxic   sequences during adolescence.   Those sequences determine how we   develop physically. Without   them...
We would never mature into adults.
Exactly. Somehow, those key   sequences were eliminated in   the Captain and the others   during transport.
So what can we do?
There are a couple of options.
These are the plants Keiko was   carrying on the shuttle. Whatever   turned the crew into children   turned these into seedlings.
We accelerated the growth on   one of them, and it developed   into a perfectly normal adult   plant.
I don't suppose that would work   on people.
No... but it does tell us that   if we do nothing, they'll probably   grow up as they did before.
That's one option...

I do have adult RVN patterns   on all four of them. I might   be able to send them back   through the Transporter pattern   buffer and replace the missing   sequences... but we can't even   attempt that until we know why   this happened in the first place.       If they were, somehow, to lose   more viroxic sequences...
They'd come back even younger.
I've got the sensor report on the   shuttle break-up.
It looks like the break-up began   near the starboard bulkhead.
There are some bulkhead fragments   over here.
My VISOR's picking up torsional   stress damage... some   micro-fractures...       Wait a minute... what's this?
Looks like tritanium from the   hull.
Yeah... but watch.
It's not tritanium anymore...   somehow the molecular structure   of the alloy's been changed --   broken down into its constituent   elements...
No wonder the bulkhead   shattered...
Let's get a sample down to   Engineering. I want to run a   metallurgical analysis.
Well, this is exciting.
Would you rather be playing with   dolls?
I'd rather be doing almost   anything other than sitting here   and watching you sulk.
This isn't some kind of glorious   second childhood, Guinan. Our   bodies have been violated...   changed... doesn't that bother   you?
Sure it bothers me, but at the   moment I can't do anything about   it. So I might as well enjoy it.
Enjoy what? Where did you get   the idea that being short and   awkward is some kind of wonderful   gift?
There must've been some part of   childhood that you didn't loathe.   Come on... tell me one happy   memory you have.
Look. It was a long, depressing   period of my life and I was   grateful when it was finally   over. I'd rather not relive it.
I bet you were a jumper.       A jumper. You know, someone who   jumped up and down on furniture   all the time.
What?
You were a jumper all right. The   quiet ones... they always look   so innocent... you think you can   turn your back on them... then   next thing you know -- bam!   They're bouncing on the bed.
That is the most ridiculous thing   I've ever heard. Most of the time   I didn't even have a bed.
Ah... but you did have one   sometimes... and I bet you jumped   on it.
I most certainly did not.
Yeah... I can see it in your   eyes... you can barely resist the   urge to leap up and start jumping   around like a Tarkassian   razorbeast.
(smiling despite     herself)   Guinan...
Oh yeah... oh yeah...
This is ridiculous.
That's right... and don't you dare   join me, Ro Laren. You don't like   jumping on beds!

We think the shuttle was caught   in a molecular reversion field,   which caused the structure of the   ship to deteriorate. When the   field penetrated the hull, it also   began to affect the shuttle crew.
When I tried to beam them off,   I wasn't able to get a lock   because the reversion field was   masking part of their patterns.
(finally     understanding)   If the Transporter only registered   part of their RVN patterns...   that would explain why the key   sequences are missing.
Exactly. And without those key   sequences, the Transporter   reconstructed them as children.
If they're right, will you be able   to use the Transporter to reverse   the effects?
I think so. As long as there's   no reversion field to mask the   patterns, we should be able to   do it.       Chief, can we adjust the molecular   imaging scanners to accept --
Bridge to Commander Riker.
Go ahead.
We're entering orbit around Ligos   Seven, sir.
On my way.       We'll discuss this later.
Standard orbit, Ensign.       Any sign of the science team?
We have been scanning the area   since entering the system, but   our readings are being disrupted.
Cause?
Extreme fluctuations in the E.M.   field.
However, there is no evidence of   relevant stellar or seismic   activity which would cause the   interference.
Any response to our hails, Mister   Worf?
No, sir. I have been attempting   to---    (suddenly sees something     on console)   Commander, two ships decloaking   fore and aft.       Klingon birds of prey... B'rel   class.
Maximum shields. Take us out   of orbit, Ensign. Mister Worf,   prepare to return fire...
Damage report.
We've lost primary life-support.   Switching to secondary systems.
Lock phasers on target bearing   to port.
Phasers locked.
Fire.
Minor damage to one ship. Its   shields are holding.
Starboard power coupling is   down... warp engines off-line.
Shields?
Down to thirteen percent.
Casualties reported on decks   twenty-six and twenty-seven...
Sensors and secondary generators   off-line... life support down   to sixty-seven percent...
Engineering, status report.
Their last shots took out   auxiliary power and emergency   back-ups. It'll take at least   an hour to get warp power back   on-line.
We've lost shields. Heavy   casualties on decks thirty-five   through forty.
I am detecting Transporter   signatures in three cargo bays.       We are being boarded.
Initiate intruder alert. All   security teams to proceed to --
Put down your weapons.
Computer, deactivate all command   functions. Authorization,   Riker-Omega-Three...
All command functions suspended.
(touches communicator     on his belt)   This is Morta. We have secured   the Bridge. Begin transporting   all able-bodied adults to the   surface.
They have locked out the command   functions.
You said they would not have time.
You led the assault team, you were   too slow.
You dare to blame me!
We have secured the ship, Daimon,   but Morta's incompetence has   denied us access to---
My incompetence! Daimon, you know   that I am --
Enough.       Where is the Captain of this ship?
I'm in command of this vessel.   Who are you and on whose authority   do you --

I am Daimon Lurin and I now   declare this ship to be a loss   and open to claim according to   the Ferengi Salvage Code. You   will cooperate with our salvage   operations or we will begin   executing your crew.
Is everyone all right?
No fatalities or injuries among   the children. The Ferengi have   control of Main Engineering and   decks twenty-three through   thirty-seven.
We have to assume they've also   taken the Bridge.
Captain... do you know what   they've done with the younger   children... with my little girl?
They're taking all the adults down   to the surface. It looks like   they're keeping all the children   on board the ship. Where was your   daughter?
In primary care on deck fourteen.
Then she's probably still there   with the others.    (off her worried     expression)   But we'll make certain.
We need to regain control of the   ship. Options?
We could flood the ship with   anesthizine gas.
That's locked out along with the   rest of the command functions.
If they're typical Ferengi,   they're probably very pleased   with themselves about now...   maybe even getting a little   overconfident.
Agreed. They might not think they   need much of their crew to hold   the ship. We could use the   element of surprise to give   ourselves a tactical advantage...
Tactical advantage... ?       Jean-Luc... look at your team for   a minute. We're children.
We can't just stay here while our   ship is being commandeered.
I'm not suggesting that we do.   But we can't act as if we were   still adults.
What do you suggest?
We look like children. Maybe it's   time we started acting like   children.
I hope your profit margin is   pretty high on this little   adventure, Lurin... because   you're risking war with the   Federation.

We're not affiliated with the   Ferengi Alliance. We're... in   business for ourselves.       And yes, it will be highly   profitable. For an investment of   two surplus Klingon ships... a few   repairs... and some weapons...   we've netted a Federation starship   and her crew, not to mention a   planet rich in Vendarite.
So that's what this is all about.   What did you do with the science   team that was on the surface?
They have proved most... helpful   in extracting the mineral.
You made them slave laborers.

The addition of your crew will   greatly speed up the process.       As for your ship... I'm sure it   will fetch a handsome price on the   Romulan market.       But before that can happen, we need   to regain access to your central   computer.
You don't really think I'm going   to help you.
I think... that the mines on Ligos   Seven can be very hazardous.
How many people in your crew?
One thousand, fourteen.
Very hazardous, Commander.
Hello. I'm the classroom   computer system. What can I do   for you, today?
Computer, display interior   security grid.
I'm sorry, but I can't do that.   Would you like to play a game?
No, I would not.       Computer, display an internal   schematic diagram.
I'm sorry, but I can't do that.   Would you like to see some   interesting animals?
It's a child's computer, remember?       Computer, can you show me a   picture of the inside of the   Enterprise?
The Enterprise is a Galaxy-class   starship. Do you know how to   spell Enterprise? E -- N -- T   -- E --
Delete audio.

All right, this will have to   do... we're here... there's a   service conduit that runs from   here to here and then connects   to a Jeffries Tube here... but   you and Ensign Ro will still have   to cross this corridor before you   can get to Main Engineering.
Captain...
Excellent.       Ready?       Make it so.
I'm sorry... Captain.
Alexander, would you mind if I...   borrowed your toy for a little   while?
Go ahead.
Thank you.
He's picked up the toy.
This is the first time these   Jeffries tubes haven't seemed   cramped.
How much farther do we have to   go?
About fifty meters... don't tell   me you're tired.
I'm not as young as I used to be.
This is it. Main Engineering.       Now we wait.
Report.
Mission accomplished, sir. The   one in Sickbay never saw me.
Very good.
I'd say we're ready. Have you   figured out how to get to the   Bridge?
I'm afraid I can only think of   one way...
What do you want?
I need to see my father.
Go back inside.
I need to see him right now.
Do not argue with me. Go back   inside.
I need him now! Now! Now! Now!
You hurt me! I want my father!   I want my father!
All right. Just stop that.
Here he is. Now be quiet!
What's going on?
Daddy!
So... son. How are you?
I'm okay.
And what about your friends...   Keiko and Guinan and Ro?
They're okay too. But...
What's wrong?
We don't have anything to do...   none of the games are working.
I know. The Ferengi made Daddy   turn off the main computer.
Can't you just turn on the kid's   computer in Schoolroom Eight?   We just want to play a few games.
I don't know if they'll let me   do that, Jean-Luc, but I'll ask.
Thanks, Number One.
He's my Number One Daddy.
How did it go?
He understood.       We should have access very soon.
Come in.
I understand your... son was here   to see you.
That's right.
We Ferengi do not bring our   offspring along with us aboard   ships.
Then I suppose that's your loss.   We consider our families to be   one of our strengths.
I think you will find they can   also be a weakness.       Unless you release the computer   to our control, I will execute   every child on this ship...   beginning with yours.
Even you aren't that cruel.
It is cruel to put children in   danger by bringing them aboard   a starship in the first place.
All right... all right... just   don't harm my son.
You will release the computer and   show Morta exactly how to use it.
Computer, release command control   to this station. Authorization,   Riker-Omega-Three.
Command functions restored.

Okay, Morta. The Enterprise   computer system is controlled by   three primary main processing   cores cross linked with a   redundant melacortz ramistat and   fourteen kiloquad interface   modules. The core elements are   based on FTL nanoprocessor units   arranged into twenty-five   bilateral kelilactirals with   twenty of those units being slaved   to the central heisenfram   terminal.       You do know what a bilateral   kelilactiral is, don't you?
Of course I do, human. I am not   stupid.

No, of course not.    (points to something     on console)   Now this is the isopalavial   interface which controls the main   firomactal drive unit.    (slaps Morta's hand     away)   Don't touch that, you'll blow up   the entire firomactal drive.
What? Wait.       What is... what is a firomactal?
Just explain it to me.
That is the firomactal drive   unit...
... it controls the central   ramistat core and also keeps the   ontarian manifold within forty   thousand KRG.
The command lockout has been   released... accessing the   transporter...       The weapon deactivation program   is in place... Transporter   security field standing by...   We're ready.
Tag!
You're it!
It's working. Your turn.
Yes?
I found this in the school room.   Is it yours?
That's all of them except for the   two on the Bridge. Wait here   until I return.
Yes, sir.
... so one more time. The   ramistat kiloquad capacity is a   function of the square root of   the intermix ratio times the sum   of the plasma injector quotient.
There's one more.
Come in. What do you want?
I believe you're in my chair.
Captain's Log, Stardate: 46236.3   We have taken Lurin and his men   into custody. The Ferengi   Alliance has quickly disavowed   any knowledge of these renegades.
With the mining operation   closed and our crew back on   board, we can now turn our   attention to other problems.
Phase inducers activated...   energy levels nominal...
I'm loading the adult patterns   into the buffer...
Transposition matrix locked   in...
Energize...
How do you feel, Captain?
I feel fine. Everything just   seems... smaller.
It's my mother.       The funny thing is... I never   really drew a picture of her when   I was young... but for some reason   I wanted to now.
That's the wonderful thing about   crayons... when you're a child,   they can take you to more places   than a starship.
It's my turn, isn't it?
Only if you're ready.
It's not quite as bad as I   remembered it... being a child,   I mean.
We better get going.
There's no hurry. The Transporter   will still be there... pass me   the burnt umber.
